I was incredibly excited when this game was first announced, but its launch‚Ä¶ well, let‚Äôs just say it didn‚Äôt go the way anyone hoped. The initial release was packed with technical and design issues - poor performance, frequent crashes, clunky movement, overwhelming enemy placement, and some truly frustrating questlines. It was rough enough that I decided to skip the game entirely at launch.

To their credit, the developers didn‚Äôt quit. Over the next two years, they listened to community feedback, released update after update, and gradually turned things around. By the time the 2.0 version arrived, a huge amount had been fixed or improved, and several new features were added. That‚Äôs when I finally felt confident enough to dive in.

Performance still isn‚Äôt perfect, but it‚Äôs far better than it used to be. After lowering reflection and global illumination to medium, I was able to play smoothly - and I haven‚Äôt had a single crash in over 66 hours of gameplay.

It‚Äôs true the game doesn‚Äôt have the ultra-polished, razor-sharp combat that FromSoftware is known for, and I think that‚Äôs a big part of why it initially received so much negativity. Expectations were sky-high, and anything less than perfection was destined to disappoint. But judged on its own merits, the game is absolutely worth playing if you enjoy Soulslikes.

Visually, it‚Äôs fantastic. The world is drenched in a dark, Gothic atmosphere that‚Äôs a joy to explore. The difficulty is challenging without crossing into ‚Äúbreak your controller‚Äù territory, and the overall journey feels rewarding and well-paced.

Ultimately, Lords of the Fallen is a strong choice for players who enjoy Souls-inspired games and want something fresh within the genre. Just don‚Äôt expect it to be a FromSoftware title - and you‚Äôll likely have a great time.

Veterans of the more difficult FromSoftware games will enjoy this game. It has an interesting and unique set of character classes, your usual panoply of difficult boss encounters, and traditional gothic trappings to go with them.

The biggest selling point of this game, however, is the Friend Pass that this game offers. You can play this game all the way through with another friend and they don't even need to buy the game if they play with you. It also runs surprisingly well on decent hardware with the use of in-engine supported upscaling.

I'd say if you want something tough to play with a friend or if you're a difficult RPG fan, give it a shot.

On top of this, finding and unlocking its specials for some of them are very obscure. Another complaint would be how precise the npc quests are where it is very easy to fail. I recommend this game to any soulsborne player. My first souls was Elden Ring - which may be a very different experience from most souls players. If you do this option, I suggest the hardest multiplayer parameters, as the game can be somewhat easy for a veteran souls player (mind you, there still is some challenge to the game). Now, if you don't care about traditional souls-like difficulty, then definitely buy this game and make your friend get the friend pass - The story draws you in, the gameplay itself is very smooth, and all aspects of roleplaying are balanced. My favorite part is how much effort they put in the distant environments, and some of the current ones. The umbral is cool as well, but in some areas it just...seems bland. Some. I played the 2.0 version of this game, with full co-op with a friend. As a co-op souls experience I thought it was really fun. The combat is pretty good, and the game is beautiful (albeit rather demanding to run). Level design was pretty good to, with secrets and unlockable shortcuts making return visits a lot quicker.

The souls 'gimmick' of this game is the second world overlayed unto the regular world. I thought this concept was really cool, but the implementation needs some work in a sequel. First an foremost, every map's umbral region has a similar look and feel, save one area that has a cool golden glow in umbral. Second, the same enemies appear in the umbral realm in every map, with a few exceptions in the earlier maps. This results in 50% of the game looking the same and playing the same with the same enemies spawning in, made the game feel more stale than it really is. Also, although the boss designs are very cool and inspired, I felt that the fights themselves were fairly mechanically simple. tbh I'd say it is excusable since this is their second attempt as a souls like, but I thought I'd mention it. The bosses aren't terrible, but they also aren't especially difficult.

There is a souls-esque multiplayer component to the game, where other players can invade to defeat you, and I thought it was really fun. I got steamrolled in the first half, but as I learned the game better, got better gear and made actual builds, I slowly started becoming the stomper instead of the stompee. Also death is not punished too hard in this game, since you can place temporary save points often. It is a really good system imo, when I experienced a trap related deaths or when a random invasion caught me off guard it wasn't the end of the world because I never lost a discouraging amount of progress.

Last but not least, I found that the world they've built is very interesting, but the story is a little vague, and especially the NPC quests were very difficult to follow. I would find an item and not know why I was able to hand it over to an NPC, nor where they would go if they moved. A lot of souls likes do this so it's by no means a big mark against this game, but again I felt it worth noting, especially since there is an interesting story and interesting NPCs, it's just hard to learn what's going on, and what choices are the "right" choices to make as the story progresses.

All in all I had a good time with the game, and although I can not judge it as a single player experience, I'd say if you have a friend that is willing to play a souls-like with you then this is a really fun time. I am really looking forward to seeing what they do with the sequel, as seamless co-op was not part of the original design for this game, but I expect the sequel will account for it more.

This game has come a long way since it's launch. While it's pretty easy as far as souls-likes go, it has some great combat mechanics that make for a very fun core. Movement is quick, responsive, and smooth. Level design that feels oppressive and rewarding at the same time, linking many areas in unexpected ways--only Dark Souls 1 and Sekiro have done it better imo (Forsaken Fen is NOT part of this praise). Each weapon class feels unique in its moveset and the ability to mix-and-match your movesets mid-combo feels awesome. It has the best ranged/casting/throwing control scheme in the genre such that even the thickest of bonk-builds have fun throwing rocks and spears. A block system that utilizes a rally-healing to keep sword-and-board engaging but also rewards perfect blocking, which deflects on an opponent's posture bar for a riposte. All of these work well in PvP, where scaling is much better now too which feels great in the ranges of lvl 30 to 150, anecdotally since October 2025 balance patch. PvP is off by default and can be opted-in, which means all these encounters are with people who want that experience.

However, as great as the movement and combat feels, all weapons within a class share the same moveset. Only fully upgraded boss weapons and some quest weapons get a unique attack, although 2 or 3 weapons stand above the rest as being overtuned. Bosses are easy, but can be replayed at any time. All the non-Remembrance bosses show up as regular enemies shortly after or later in the game. Enemies fall into three factions, of which 80% of them you meet early on, so later sections can only add one new enemy if you're lucky. This enemy variety is easily the biggest issue with the game, especially as most of these enemies fall over under a soft breeze. Considering holding back weapon upgrades as you progress otherwise even big enemies will die in one hit.

Overall it's a very fun, co-op oriented introduction to the souls-like genre. I think it's the most accessible of its type and the friend's pass is excellent value. Lack of enemy variety is a disservice to its combat system, but at least everything is fun to fight with and the game provides near-unlimited respecs

Played the first one so had some reluctance on this but it was really good. I didn't experience it at launch which is I guess where some of the less than positive reviews must have came from. This is a great game to add to the list of successful soulslikes in my book.

Game's good, though there are some "buts". 

As for positives, the levels design is REALLY good, it has a soulslike bread and butter of labyrinthine maps, but the game manages to avoid the classic toxic elements that so many others feel the unquenchable need to include just because FromSoftware does. That means LotF doesn't have the "mandatory" poison level designed strictly to make you as miserable as possible as you drudge for 2 hours knee-deep in poison. It doesn't have the second "mandatory" high-elevation level of mobs shooting at you from half across the map while other mobs jump out from behind crates to attempt to knock you down. This alone is such a breath of fresh air in a genre that is mostly trying to outdo the competition in how much you can break the players' balls rather than try something new and unique.

Now, LotF does have something that is absolutely new and unique - the lamp mechanic. This is not a simple gimmick, the world is actually split into 2 dimensions that almost fully overlap - and they do that in real time. It's not a simple switch/lever mechanic that actually just reloads the world without you noticing, you can actually just flash the lamp for a second and see mobs in the second dimension, and they can see you and try to drag you there when you do. All that ties perfectly into the level and the entire world design and is easily the game's strongest point. The game is worth playing just for that alone.

The game sadly also has 2 fairly big negatives. First, the walking animation. Oh, the walking animation. Especially with great weapons, it looks so artificial. The weapons actually look like inflatable sticks (only while walking, though they do look and feel like they have weight when swinging), but that's not even the worst part - that would be the fact that there are no footsteps and the character moves so fast that it feels like it's just hovering a few milimetres above ground. I don't know how that was approved, you'd think in a game where you mostly are running around, the animation needs to be mostly perfect.
Second, the difficulty level. I've played the game in 2025, I've seen mentions that it was extremely hard when it just came out back in 2023 - unfortunately, that is not the case anymore. The game is by FAR the easiest soulslike I've ever played, it is actually just trivial - great weapons allow you to kill most bosses within several hits (4 was my record while playing the game normally, I'm pretty sure I could go down to 2 or 3 with some min-maxing), and then later in the game you get access to an item that allows you uninterruptable charged attacks while the damage you take while charging is coverted to recoverable health - which means you're essentially immortal as long as you don't die while charging the attack. That completely breaks the game and while obviously you don't have to use that build, the fact it's allowed at all is baffling. I suspect it wouldn't be much harder with other builds, though - the bosses really don't deal much damage and have little HP.

If you can overlook both of these issues, though, the game is really worth playing just for the lamp mechanic, which is actually a small revolution in a genre that is getting pretty stale with the gameplay and map designs.

When I first played Lord of the Fallen on my old Steam account, I actually found it quite enjoyable. However, the performance issues were pretty bad at the time. Now that I‚Äôve come back to try it again, I can say the developers have really improved the performance. The game now runs smoothly, and I no longer have to worry about stutters or FPS drops.

As for the gameplay if you‚Äôve ever played any Soulsborne titles from FromSoftware, this is a game you shouldn‚Äôt miss. Lord of the Fallen includes many mechanics that fans of Demon‚Äôs Souls, Bloodborne, Dark Souls 1‚Äì3, or even Sekiro would find familiar. I often see people saying that the controls feel too complicated or that the regular enemies are too tough. But honestly, to me, that‚Äôs perfectly normal this is a Souls-like game, after all. If it were easy, that would be strange, wouldn‚Äôt it?

I‚Äôm trying to be as neutral as possible here I‚Äôm not trying to overpraise it. I‚Äôve played many Souls-like games before, starting with Dark Souls 1, then Demon‚Äôs Souls back on the PS3, followed by Bloodborne, Sekiro, and finally Elden Ring. But Lord of the Fallen really gives that familiar Souls-like atmosphere while still offering its own unique feel. So if you‚Äôre looking for a fresh take on the genre, I‚Äôd definitely recommend giving it a try.

Oh, and I almost forgot the online system is surprisingly good for a modern Souls-like. It‚Äôs kind of annoying because you have to summon your friend again every time, and some areas don‚Äôt even allow co-op at all (any Elden Ring players will know what I mean).

Although I beat the game and am excited for Lords of the Fallen 2, there are 3 reasons to why I cannot recommend this game. None of them are a big issue in and of themselves, however, when together and compounded in this 25-hours title, really detract from the overall experience. 
Give my review a read and decide for yourself, the game is fun but these were my gripes:

Reason 1 - Quest progression and main story choices - this game's quests and even the main story is clearly inspired by dark souls' annoying teleporting NPCs with weird random item requirements and the ability to lock you out of quests (you can miss out on vendors, gear, endings). This game takes it up a notch, failing a quest here is so easy that I would recommend a new player to follow a build guide just so they don't need to start a new game+ to get a spell or unlock a weapon's special attack. trust me! you'll need a walkthrough.

Reason 2 - Visual clarity and level design - this game has a parallel world mechanic, (similar to *that level* in Titanfall 2) where the other world has hidden areas and items in addition to some areas only being accessible through the Umbral world, as it is called. This would be fine if there was a reason to play in the normal world. As it stands, all you get is and extra life, Sekiro style. I cannot tell how many items I missed because they only exist in the Umbral which forced me to play every level twice. By the end of the game, I was playing every level in the other world. OK! so what's the issue you may ask? when in the Umbral, the level is covered in fungi and a horrid blue tint and fog, although it looks fantastic (this game really is beautiful) for an interactive media, the lack of visual clarity means that enemies blend in with the environment, you miss items, areas or simply get lost due to not being able to find your bearings. I had to scour the internet in order to find a way to turn off this volumetric fog and all the modern-day visual artifacts that plague DLSS infested games. I suggest you do the same! not to mention, while in the Umbral, areas which have distinctive themes all end up looking so similar to each other that you couldn't tell what differentiates one area from the other.

Reason 3 - Enemy variety. simply put this game doesn't have enough enemies that challenge how you play, this may be a personal belief which could lead to a bias of mine, but I do think enemies in any video game should serve a purpose, to test their players quick thinking, strategy and flexibility. This game gets a praise in terms of enemy placement, they are all amazingly positioned, keeping you on toes, but the variety is just not enough! by hour 10, you've seen every enemy the game has to offer, and they don't offer much of a challenge either, you can stagger them to death, when you don't out-right kill them in 2 hits.

Praises - the game is very big, well worth you money; it looks stunning once you get past the issues I mentioned; weapon variety is crazy; every build is viable if you don't fail their respective questlines; and the other world mechanic, although flawed, is breath of fresh air into the genre.

I beat this game. Don't play it.

The level design is atrociously bad. Paths go absolutely nowhere and literally every Dark Souls-esque "shortcut" is completely useless - why do I need a shortcut from one rest spot to get back to the previous one when I can warp between them? The layout of areas meanders around and makes it difficult to see when you've actually made progress, especially since there are paths that run off everywhere and lead to nothing.

It has some incredibly cool concepts and QoL stuff that had me really hopeful - the "two worlds" thing seems especially cool, but it just absolutely craps the bed when it comes to using it. The entire Umbral World looks exactly the same no matter where you are and it's just DULL. The cross-platform invasions and co-op seems like a great idea, in fact the co-op could be, I haven't tried it, but invasions have no level matching, meaning every time it happened to me it was someone with endgame gear. I can imagine how annoying that is from their perspective too, wanting a challenge and ending up taking a gamble every invasion on whether it'll be a waste of time.

It's also pretty dreadfully easy. I struggled with one boss fight that you are designed to lose TWICE throughout the game. When I finally got to fight it properly, it lasted about a minute and a half and presented no challenge at all.

I wanted to like it. I'd heard good things. The only thing I can say I enjoyed about it is that loading it up and watching something on another monitor was pretty chill.

Smart boss mechanics? This is Lords of the Fallen, brostate. You'll either have an easy bossfight or you're getting jumped.

I enjoyed my time with this game but whilst exploring an expansive castle level I got hit with the unmistakable feeling of sheer boredom. It was caused by an abundance of enemies that are almost all reused from the very first level onward. Basic mage stick guy, two-handed mace guy, crossbow dude, one-handed mace shield guy and some dogs over and over and over again. 

The Umbral Realm is even worse about this. It's just a bunch of waddling zombies and occasionally a fat fly, rare sickle dudes and a few big guys who only take damage from behind. But it's just 99% waddling zombies which gets very old, very quick. 

Enemies you encounter as minibosses are quickly turned into mob types that are littered throughout the next levels, only adding to the tedium as you become more familiar with them. One of the worst offenders is a large two-handed weapon type of enemy that has a few distinct models but each one uses the same exact moveset. 

I'm no stranger to reused enemies, I love Elden Ring and it has plenty of recolored / reused enemies. But ER nonetheless has a vast quantity more enemy variety compared to this game. Even Limgrave and Weeping Peninsula alone has probably triple the amount of enemy variety compared to this game.

The apparently "shared" co-op progression is totally broken with many key items and mechanics just straight up never being accessible to the 2nd player.

How this game is still in such an abysmal state two whole years after launch is beyond me. Embarrassing. 

You guys owe my friend a power supply.
